lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 11** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/duke.duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run duke.duke.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
* A public constructor of the deadline class.
public Deadline(String name, LocalDateTime date, String input) {
* A string representation of the deadline class.
formatter = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM dd yyyy, h:mm a");
* A class that represents a ChatBot.
* Interacts with the user based on the input received.
* @param name extracted from the original input
* @param from extracted from the original input
* @param to extracted from the original input
* @param input the input that user keyed in
public Event(String name, String from, String to, String input) {

* @return String that contains the Event name, timeframe and flags.

* @param input the input that user entered
* @param isLoading a flag to check if the application is restoring
public void handleInput(String input, TaskList taskList, Boolean isLoading) {

* @param isLoading a flag to check if the application is restoring
public void handleTodo(String input, TaskList taskList, Boolean isLoading) {

* @param input the input that user entered
* @param isLoading a flag to check if the application is restoring
public void handleEvent(String input, TaskList taskList, Boolean isLoading) {
String[] arr1 = input.split("/from "); // [0]: event + name, [1]: timeframe
Task event = new Event(arr3[1], arr2[0], arr2[1], input);
* Handles inputs that start with deadline.
* @param input the input that user entered
* @param isLoading a flag to check if the application is restoring
public void handleDeadline(String input, TaskList taskList, Boolean isLoading) {
String[] arr1 = input.split("/by "); // 0: deadline + name , 1: date
Task deadline = new Deadline(arr2[1], formattedDate, input);
* Converts the string date and time to a LocalDateTime object.

* @return LocalDateTime that allows the reformatting of date and time
* @throws DateTimeParseException an exception when the format of date is invalid
public static LocalDateTime dateFormatter(String dateTime) throws DateTimeParseException {
* Add the individual task into the taskList and saves them into a file.

public void AddTask(Task task, TaskList taskList, Boolean isLoading) {
* Find tasks based on a target string that the user entered.

public void findMatching(String keyword, TaskList taskList) {
* A class that contains the save and load methods

* @param filepath directs to the file containing the saved content
* @param parser handles the content in the file
* @return a TaskList that contains the tasks from the content
public static TaskList load(String filepath, Parser parser) {
* Saves the task-list into the file whenever a change is made
* Represents a task entered by the user.

* @param name extracted from the user input
* A method that changes the done flag.

* Prints to standard output a greeting message.
System.out.println("Hello! I'm lippy the wombat\n" + "What can I do for you?");
System.out.println("Bye. Hope to see you again soon!");
* Prints when the input is not recognised
System.out.println("☹ OOPS!!! I'm sorry, but I don't know what that means :-(");
* Prints when a new task is added.
public static void printAddTask(Task task, TaskList taskList) {
System.out.println("Got it. I've added this task:\n" + task + "\n"
+ "Now you have " + taskList.size() + " tasks in the list.");
* Prints to the input list when the list is empty.
System.out.println("There is currently no items in the list");
* Prints to an input list when list is not empty.
System.out.println("Here are the tasks in your list:");
* Prints when the user marks a task done.
System.out.println("Nice! I've marked this task as done:" + "\n" + task);
* Prints when the user unmarks a task.
System.out.println("OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:" + "\n" + task);
* Prints when an IndexOutOfBounds exception is thrown.
* Prints when a NumberFormatException is thrown.
* Prints when a task gets deleted.
* @param deleted of type String that represents the deleted task
public static void removeTask(String deleted, TaskList taskList) {
System.out.println("Noted. I've removed this task:\n" + deleted + "\n"
+ "Now you have " + taskList.size() + " tasks in the list.");
* Prins when todo description is empty.

System.out.println("Here are the matching tasks in your list:");
System.out.println("description of a find command cannot be empty");
